	* The method involves forming a film on the superconducting material, adding oxygen, and heat treating the material to maintain ideal oxygen concentration at the surface for long-term stability.
* Different films such as silicon nitride, silicon oxide, and aluminum can be used for coating, with oxygen added through ion injection and heat treatment to ensure uniform oxygen concentration throughout the material.
	* The method allows for the creation of a passivation film to prevent deterioration and maintain superconductivity at the surface, improving the reliability of superconducting devices.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention is an apparatus for preparing foam sheet samples for microscopic examination.
	• The apparatus allows for precise cutting of foam sheet samples for detailed analysis.
• The method preserves the cell structure of the foam samples, allowing for examination without distortion.
	• The parallel orientation of the cut surfaces enables even transmission of light for microscopic examination.
• The apparatus provides a systematic way to prepare foam samples for physical tests and performance criteria evaluation.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to seismometers designed for ocean floor operation, determining angle of inclination, and leveling seismic motion detectors.
	* Seismometers are crucial for geological research, especially in oil and gas exploration.
* Ocean bottom seismometers (OBS) face challenges due to remote deployment and lack of control over placement.
	* The invention provides a method to determine the angle of inclination and preserve the orientation of the seismometer.
* The invention includes a method and apparatus for automatically leveling seismic motion detectors.
	* Geophones are commonly used as seismic motion detectors.
* The invention involves suspending the detector at the end of a shaft protruding from a rotating ball to form a pendulum.
	* A spring-loaded plunger is used to lock the detector in position.
* The detector, support means, solenoid, and plunger are mounted inside a water-tight instrument housing.
	* The invention ensures good acoustic coupling between the ocean bottom and the detector.
* The solenoid is activated to remove a pin, allowing the plunger to lock the detector in place.
	* The angle of inclination can be determined by measuring the position of the locked detector.
* The invention aims to provide a simple and inexpensive method for determining inclination angle and leveling seismic detectors on ocean floor seismometers.
</summary>

<summary>
• The humidity sensing element of the present invention consists of a first electron conductive electrode, a porous dielectric coating with nickel particles, and a second electron conductive electrode.
	• The first electrode is made of aluminum anodized with oxalic acid, with nickel particles deposited in the porosity of the dielectric.
		• The anodized layer is sealed to reduce porosity and the second electrode is formed by vacuum deposition of nickel.
		• The impedance between the electrodes varies linearly with the relative humidity of the surrounding atmosphere when excited by an alternating current voltage.
• The method of manufacturing the humidity sensing element involves coating the first electrode with a porous dielectric, depositing nickel particles, and forming the second electrode.
	• The first electrode is anodized aluminum, nickel particles are vacuum deposited into the dielectric, and the second electrode is formed by vacuum deposition of nickel.
		• The anodized layer is sealed after nickel deposition, and the second electrode is formed by vacuum deposition of nickel.
		• The resulting sensor has a linear response to relative humidity and is suitable for use in controlling humidity in various applications.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a motor assembly with a force transmission structure for a window lift system in a vehicle.
    * The force transmission structure includes a drive plate with a Y-shaped mounting hole and a shaft with a Y-shaped toothed portion.
    * The drive plate is made of engineering plastics material and has buffer holes for relief during molding.
    * The shaft is rotated stably by three equal forces exerted on the three teeth of the toothed portion, resulting in quiet operation and reduced noise.
* The motor assembly also includes a worm, worm gear, damper, and pinion for driving the window lift system.
    * The worm is driven by the motor shaft and meshes with the worm gear, which rotates the drive plate through the damper.
    * The damper is made of rubber and has slots for engaging with the protrusions of the drive plate.
    * The shaft is held captive within the mounting hole by a circlip to prevent it from escaping during operation.
* The drive plate has V-shaped protrusions and ribs for engaging with the damper and driving member.
    * The protrusions are shaped to fit the second slots of the damper and increase in width gradually from the inner to outer portions.
    * The drive plate is rotated by the damper and worm gear, which in turn rotates the shaft to drive the window lift system.
    * The connection between the shaft and drive plate can withstand greater torque due to the increased contact area between the teeth and mounting hole.
* The design of the force transmission structure improves stability, reduces noise, and allows for quiet operation of the window lift system.
    * The use of engineering plastics material for the drive plate and rubber for the damper helps absorb vibration and reduce noise.
    * The Y-shaped mounting hole and toothed portion provide a stable connection between the shaft and drive plate, resulting in smooth operation.
    * The buffer holes in the drive plate aid in molding and reduce distortion of the mounting hole during cooling.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention is related to wireless communication systems, specifically for detection, identification, and monitoring of multipath signals in WCDMA systems.
    • Background information on wireless communication systems and the evolution towards 3G systems is provided.
    • The invention provides a method and system for generating a mobile time reference for a portable transceiver.
    • The system includes an antenna, radio frequency subsystem, and baseband subsystem.
• A method of generating a mobile time reference is outlined, involving high and low frequency clocks.
    • The mobile time reference is generated using the high frequency clock and maintained using the low frequency clock during idle mode.
    • The mobile time reference is updated with the low frequency clock cycles and drift estimate during idle mode.
    • When transitioning to active mode, the updated mobile time reference is used as a starting point.
• Detailed diagrams and descriptions of the portable transceiver system, free running counter, and multipath signal recovery circuit are provided.
    • The system includes components such as primary sync searcher, secondary sync searcher, and gold code searcher.
    • The multipath radio signal recovery circuit includes SPPs, FIFO circuits, phase correctors, MRCs, and demodulation units.
    • The system efficiently recovers and processes multipath signals in the presence of moving time base, slotted operations, and mobile radio channel effects.
</summary>

<summary>
* Protective helmets with hard outer shells are known in the art, typically with a resilient liner assembly to absorb shock.
	* Previous methods for custom-fitted liners involved foam injection or preformed cells, but had limitations.
* A new method involves layers of elastic thermoplastic sheets with open pockets, allowing for rapid and simple fitting to a wearer's head.
	* The sheets are deformed by heating, placed between an outer fixture and the head, and cooled to a rigid state for a custom fit.
* The liner does not require filling with spacer elements, allowing for compliance and conforming to the wearer's head contours.
	* This eliminates the need for maintaining layers in register, simplifying manufacturing and reducing shifting of the helmet.
* The liner is assembled with comfort foam and inner lining, and fastened to the outer shell with hook-and-loop fasteners.
	* Different sizes are fabricated to accommodate a range of head sizes, with adjustments made by deforming the sheets during fitting.
* The fitting process can be repeated to accommodate size changes, such as hair length or bumps on the head.
	* The liner is simple and inexpensive to manufacture, does not require drawstrings, and does not need trimming after fitting.
* The helmet liner provides a uniform structure, resists shifting on the wearer's head, and can be refitted easily for different head sizes.
	* The method allows for rapid and simple fitting, with predictable structural characteristics and no tension maintenance during size adjustment.
</summary>

<summary>
• Multiorifice structure for fuel injector valves
    • Made by fusing concentric layers of rods and cylindrical members
        • Rods are angularly disposed with respect to the axis
        • Interstices between rods and cylinders form passageways
        • Passageways increase in angle from center of structure
        • Thickness of structure affects directional component of fluid flow
• Advantages include improved atomization and uniformity of apertures
    • Triangular orifices enhance surface tension forces for better atomization
    • Rods made with precise tolerances for uniform aperture size
    • Coating rods and cylinders with lower melting temperature material aids fusion
    • Sliced into thin structures for use in fuel injector valves
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a method of manufacturing a semiconductor device with an insulated gate field effect structure and a lightly doped drain (LDD) structure.
	* Conventional methods face challenges in controlling the width of the oxide portion on the gate sidewall and preventing hot carrier injection into the oxide film.
* The method involves forming an insulating film on the gate electrode, depositing a layer on the insulating film, anisotropically etching the layer to leave a portion on the gate sidewall, and forming high and low density n-type regions.
	* This approach improves controllability of the oxide portion width and prevents degradation of device performance due to hot-carrier injection.
* Different embodiments involve using polycrystalline silicon, oxide, high melting point metal, or silicides for the sidewall portion, and siliciding the gate electrode and source/drain regions.
	* Siliciding helps prevent transconductance degradation and reduces resistances, while also allowing for shallow junctions and minimizing device size.
* Additional variations include forming amorphous regions, using inert gas ions for amorphization, and employing rapid or low-temperature annealing for activation.
	* These techniques enable precise control over device characteristics and facilitate the fabrication of smaller, high-performance semiconductor devices.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to an improved end-user interface for Internet-protocol (IP) telephone communication.
  * Internet telephony is becoming a competitor to conventional telephony for long distance calls at low cost.
  * Current IP telephones consist of a multimedia PC running a software telephony application.
  * The software telephony application compresses and decompresses speech signals for network transmission.
  * The enhanced radio telephone can operate as a conventional radio telephone or an improved IP telephone.
  * The enhanced radio telephone includes an internal speech coder for low power consumption and reduced speech delay.
* The enhanced radio telephone can be connected to a PC via cable or wireless connection.
  * Coded speech signals are exchanged between the enhanced radio telephone and the PC.
  * IP-telephone control can be initiated from either the PC or the enhanced radio telephone.
  * The enhanced radio telephone can switch between wireless and IP-telephone operation manually or automatically.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to devices for producing electrical power, pressurized water, or other useful work from surface waves on a water body.
	* The energy captured is from submerged devices relying on wave-induced subsurface differences in hydrostatic pressure and enhanced surge or pitch.
* Wave energy commercialization lags behind wind energy despite the higher energy density of water compared to air.
	* Most current wave energy converters suffer from high costs and low efficiency due to heavy steel construction and near shore deployment.
* The present invention uses gas-filled containers that deform in response to wave-induced pressure changes, capturing both hydrostatic and hydrokinetic wave energy.
	* The invention enhances energy capture with overhead floating bodies and allows for depth adjustment for tides and sea-state survivability.
* Prior art devices use multiple containers or rigid structures, limiting stroke length and energy capture efficiency.
	* The present invention uses flexible reinforced bellows, partial evacuation, and surface venting to increase stroke length and energy capture.
* The invention also includes features like wave focusing, reflection, and diffraction techniques to increase energy capture efficiency.
	* Mechanical connections to floating devices and adjustable depth mooring systems further enhance energy capture and survivability.
</summary>

<summary>
• Scraped surface heat exchangers are widely used in industries like food processing.
    • They consist of a cylindrical outer tube with a central drive shaft for mixing and scraping.
    • Blades are hingedly connected to the drive shaft with pins for mixing and preventing material buildup.
    • Installation of blades on the drive shaft can be cumbersome, especially in vertically arranged heat exchangers.
• A new method involves blades with locking tracks on both sides for easy mounting.
    • Blades have mounting holes and L-shaped locking tracks for engagement with pins.
    • Pins have inner and outer fingers for secure connection with the blade.
    • Blades are inserted at an angle, slid onto the pins, and then rotated into place for installation.
• The locking tracks prevent blades from falling off during installation or operation.
    • Blades can only be removed by raising them to a certain position for sliding off the pins.
    • Tracks on both sides of the blade reduce wear and ensure structural rigidity.
    • This method simplifies the mounting process and ensures correct orientation of the blades.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a process and an apparatus for detecting and eliminating defective or incorrectly positioned cigarettes in a cigarette magazine.
    * Cigarettes can become transversely located in the magazine, causing blockages in shafts and disrupting production.
    * An optical checking element, such as a camera, scans an image of the cigarettes in the magazine for evaluation.
    * Deviations from a reference image or value trigger an error signal for detection of transversely located cigarettes.
* The process and apparatus can also detect defective cigarettes, such as missing filters or bent cigarettes.
    * Detected disruptions can be eliminated manually or automatically by actuating ejecting units.
    * Ejecting units are arranged in the magazine to push out a group of cigarettes, including the defective one.
    * The front and rear walls of the ejecting units are designed to prevent jamming and ensure smooth ejection.
* Multiple cameras can be used for more reliable detection of defects in the cigarettes.
    * Ejecting zones are assigned to evaluation zones for targeted ejection of defective cigarettes.
    * Actuation of ejecting units can be triggered automatically based on detected defects or manually for sampling purposes.
    * The combination of automatic detection and ejection of defective cigarettes provides the greatest advantages for production efficiency.
</summary>

<summary>
* Device for interconnecting high voltage cables with apparatus or other cables
  * Simplified connection system for cables up to 400 KV
  * Common interface for all accessories and interconnections
* Three interface methods: inner cone, outer cone, no cone
  * Inner cone separates cable connection further from apparatus
  * Outer cone easier to expand rubber material than compress it
* Applications include SF6 terminal, transformer terminal, outdoor terminal
  * SF6 terminal has compact design, lower cost, standardization
  * Transformer terminal enhances safety by omitting oil-filled box
* Straight through joint, transition joint, joint between two apparatus
  * Quick installation, lower cost, compact design
  * Rigid insulator angle between 15° and 45° for high operating reliability
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a fixing mechanism for a tool for material treatment, such as machining, with applications in various technologies including machining by chipping, robot applications, and cutting, punching, molding, and forming work.
	* The fixing mechanism features connecting surfaces in the tool frame and tool holder shaped as curved surfaces, allowing for simple and secure tool fixation, transmission of machining force, and frictional contact.
		* The tool frame surrounds the curved connecting surface in the tool holder, with contact surfaces in the final mounting phase transmitting machining force in the mounting direction and allowing for release by a propulsive force.
		* Clamps are used to fix the tool frame to the tool holder, with a groove-nose joint system facilitating mounting and release of the tool, ensuring a secure and efficient fixing mechanism.
* Different embodiments of the fixing mechanism are presented, including variations in the shape and placement of connecting surfaces, the use of ball mechanisms for fixation, and the design of mounting elements for tool frame attachment to the tool holder.
	* Curvilinear surfaces are utilized in both the tool frame and tool holder, with variations in the design of connecting elements and clamps to achieve effective tool fixation and release mechanisms.
	* The fixing mechanism allows for easy mounting and release of tools, ensuring a reliable and efficient process for material treatment applications in various industries.
</summary>

<summary>
* Switching regulator circuits have been modified to reduce EMI by interleaving source and drain paths, canceling out EMI produced in each path.
	* The addition of terminal leads further reduces EMI by absorbing leaking EMI fields generated by adjacent paths.
</summary>

<summary>
* Vehicle battery rebalancing is performed to correct cell voltage imbalance conditions by measuring cell voltages, bleeding down cells, and charging the battery.
* A power system may include a battery with multiple cells, with a controller causing cells to acquire charge for a period of time to equalize voltages, with different charge rates among cells.
    * Up to 50% of the time taken to rebalance and charge a battery may be dedicated to rebalancing.
    * Methods are provided to reduce the time spent rebalancing and charging vehicle batteries.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention is an AC-to-DC converter for lamp power supply that eliminates low and high frequency flicker, reducing eye fatigue and protecting eyesight and health.
	• Three main categories of power supply for lamps currently exist: low frequency voltage output, high frequency voltage output, and high frequency voltage in a low frequency envelope.
• The converter includes various circuits such as input protection, EMI filter, rectifier, filter, converter, output filter, lamp, start circuit, control circuit, biasing circuit, sampling circuit, output protection circuit, feedback and dimming circuit, and input monitor circuit.
	• Different implementations of the converter can be used, with various topologies and components, to achieve the goal of converting AC input voltage to a constant DC output voltage without flicker or electromagnetic radiation.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention provides a system for controlling lighting levels in a space using a combination of daylight and electric lighting.
   • The system includes sensors for detecting illumination levels, dimmable electric lamps, and motorized window treatments.
   • The system uses a closed-loop algorithm to adjust the dimming levels of electric lamps based on the sensed illumination levels.
• The system also controls window treatments to prevent sun glare, based on the readings of photosensors.
   • The window treatments are adjusted based on the sun angle above the horizon to reduce glare.
   • The system employs a dead-band range for light levels to prevent unnecessary adjustments.
• The system adjusts the set points for electric lights and window treatments based on the time of day and the sun angle.
   • The set points are varied to compensate for changes in daylight availability and to minimize glare.
   • The system integrates illumination maintenance and glare control in a single control algorithm.
</summary>

<summary>
* Before September 2001, significant vulnerabilities in aviation security were identified, including weaknesses in screening passengers and baggage, controlling access to secure areas at airports, and protecting air traffic control computer systems and facilities.
	* Screeners often failed to detect threat objects due to rapid turnover and insufficient training.
	* Controls for limiting access to secure areas of airports did not always work as intended.
* The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) was created to address these weaknesses and establish security requirements with mandated deadlines.
	* TSA deployed federal screeners at commercial airports and implemented explosives detection technology for checked baggage.
	* TSA confiscated prohibited items from passengers and expanded the Federal Air Marshal Service.
* The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) remained responsible for security of air traffic control systems and facilities.
	* FAA focused on enhancing the security of air traffic control systems and completing background investigations of contractor employees.
* TSA faced challenges in meeting deadlines and achieving goals, such as expanding the Federal Air Marshal Service and deploying explosives detection systems.
	* TSA granted waivers to airports for delays in screening checked baggage and faced concerns about meeting new deadlines.
* TSA pursued initiatives to strengthen control over access to secure areas of airports, such as establishing a Transportation Workers Identification Card program.
	* TSA continued to develop the Computer Assisted Passenger Prescreening System II and requested funding for a registered traveler program.
* TSA faced challenges in managing its workforce, reducing the screener workforce, and establishing a performance management system.
	* TSA worked to build a results-oriented culture within the Department of Homeland Security and improve coordination with federal, state, and local agencies.
</summary>

<summary>
* LDA and IRC sections 4911 and 162(e) have different purposes and cover different types of lobbying activities.
    * LDA requires registration and reporting of lobbying efforts to provide public disclosure of attempts by paid lobbyists to influence federal officials.
    * IRC section 4911 limits lobbying by 501(c)(3) organizations to clarify the extent they can lobby without jeopardizing their tax-exempt status.
    * IRC section 162(e) denies federal income tax deductibility of certain lobbying expenses for businesses.
* LDA requires organizations to register with the Secretary of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives within 45 days of making a lobbying contact.
    * Registration includes information such as the organization's name, client's name, names of lobbyists, issues addressed, and affiliated organizations.
    * Organizations must register if lobbying expenses exceed $20,500 during a 6-month reporting period.
    * Employees must spend at least 20% of their time engaged in lobbying activities to be listed as lobbyists.
* Organizations can choose to use either the LDA definition or the applicable IRC definition for calculating lobbying expenses.
    * Using an IRC definition may result in different reporting requirements and disclosures.
    * Most organizations reported using the LDA definition for reporting lobbying expenses.
    * Organizations using the IRC section 162(e) definition reported the highest mean and median expenses.
* Differences in the definitions can affect who must register and what they must report under LDA.
    * The choice of definition can significantly impact registration thresholds and reporting requirements.
    * Using an IRC definition may result in less disclosure and unrelated information being reported.
* Options for harmonizing the definitions, eliminating the use of IRC definitions, or requiring only federal lobbying expenses under IRC definitions are considered.
    * Harmonizing the definitions could ensure consistent reporting but may require significant changes to existing policies.
    * Eliminating the use of IRC definitions could increase reporting burden for some organizations.
    * Requiring only federal lobbying expenses under IRC definitions could improve alignment with LDA's purpose but may not fully address reporting discrepancies.
* The trade-offs for each option must be carefully considered to determine the best approach for ensuring public disclosure of lobbying activities.
    * Harmonizing the definitions may be disproportionate to the problem of misalignment in reporting.
    * Eliminating the use of IRC definitions or requiring only federal lobbying expenses could improve reporting consistency but may impose additional burdens on organizations.
</summary>

<summary>
• GAO has been assessing strategic sourcing and its potential value for federal acquisitions for over a decade.
	• Leading companies have successfully implemented strategic sourcing for services, resulting in substantial savings.
	• Private sector companies use spend analysis as a foundation for strategic procurement.
		• Spend analysis provides insight into spending, buyers, suppliers, and opportunities for savings.
		• Federal agencies face challenges in obtaining reliable spending data and expertise for strategic sourcing.
• The Federal Strategic Sourcing Initiative (FSSI) was established in 2005 to leverage government-wide buying power.
	• FSSI has achieved significant savings through strategic sourcing initiatives.
	• Agencies face disincentives for participating in strategic sourcing, such as fear of budget cuts and lack of centralized information on contracts.
</summary>

<summary>
* Current surface transportation programs face challenges due to lack of clear vision and federal role
    * Programs not linked to performance or needs, distributed through formulas
    * Lack of rigorous economic analysis in project selection
    * Fiscal sustainability of programs funded by Highway Trust Fund in doubt
* Federal surface transportation programs have expanded in complexity and goals
    * Majority of funds dedicated to highway infrastructure
    * Various grant structures and federal approaches for distributing funds
    * Lack of clarity in federal role and conflicting goals affecting program effectiveness
* Need for a reexamination of federal approach to surface transportation problems
    * Framework of principles to guide restructuring and funding proposals
    * Principles include creating well-defined goals, establishing federal role, incorporating performance and accountability, employing best tools and approaches, ensuring fiscal sustainability
* Various funding and financing options needed to address transportation funding shortfalls
    * Options include altering existing or introducing new funding approaches, using financing mechanisms
    * User fees, taxes, bonding, loans, credit assistance, revolving funds, public-private partnerships among financing mechanisms
* Importance of considering public interest and national interests in highway public-private partnerships
    * Need for up-front analysis of public interest
    * Federal role in identifying and protecting national interests in partnerships
</summary>

<summary>
• FAA engages in three primary activities: aviation safety oversight, ATC, and airport infrastructure development
	• Costs associated with safety activities driven by volume of licenses and inspections
	• ATC services provided from control towers, TRACONs, and ARTCCs
• AIP funds airport infrastructure development, not directly related to user costs
	• Trust Fund established to fund airport and airway system development
</summary>

<summary>
* DOD conducted tests on military personnel during World War II, exposing them to chemical substances.
    * Approximately 60,000 military personnel were used as human experimental subjects.
    * Unknown numbers of additional servicemembers may have been exposed through production, transportation, and storage.
    * Efforts were made to identify and notify individuals potentially exposed during these tests.
    * DOD lacked information about individuals exposed during secret tests.
* DOD initiated efforts to identify individuals exposed during Project 112 tests.
    * A database was created with information on approximately 6,400 potentially exposed individuals.
    * Certificates of commendation were sent to over 700 individuals.
    * A task force was established to monitor DOD's efforts.
    * Congress continued to investigate the issue through hearings and reports.
</summary>

<summary>
* The government of Mexico has been combating criminal groups, including DTOs, since the 1980s and 1990s.
	* President Felipe Calderón mobilized the military and law enforcement in 2006 to disrupt DTO operations.
* Mexican DTOs engage in various criminal activities, including trafficking narcotics, human trafficking, and money laundering.
	* They rely on firearms acquired from the United States to assert control over territory and resist government operations.
* DTOs use "straw purchasers" to acquire firearms illegally in the United States.
	* Firearms are often obtained from unlicensed private sellers at gun shows and flea markets.
* Concerns exist that violence from DTOs along the U.S.-Mexico border is spilling over into the United States.
	* The U.S. and Mexico have committed to working together to combat criminal organizations, including arms trafficking.
* The Mérida Initiative provides assistance to Mexico to fight organized crime and combat firearms trafficking.
	* ATF and ICE are the primary agencies combating illicit sales and trafficking of firearms across the Southwest border.
* ATF traces firearms seized in crimes in Mexico back to the United States and conducts investigations to identify and prosecute individuals involved in firearms trafficking.
	* ICE enforces U.S. export laws and targets the illegal movement of firearms to prevent procurement by criminal organizations.
* Challenges in information sharing and disagreement on agency roles have emerged between ATF and ICE in combating firearms trafficking.
	* The U.S. and Mexican governments have taken steps to enhance collaboration and combat firearms trafficking, including training and joint investigations.
* The indicator used in the Strategy to track progress in combating firearms trafficking is not sufficient to measure the effectiveness of U.S. agencies' efforts.
	* ONDCP should establish a more comprehensive set of indicators to evaluate progress in combating arms trafficking to Mexico.
</summary>

<summary>
* Each state has a central repository for criminal history information.
    * Information is contributed by law enforcement agencies, prosecutors, courts, and corrections agencies.
    * Criminal history records are compiled for each individual offender.
    * Records contain relevant identifiers and information about arrests and dispositions.
    * Efforts to improve criminal history records have been ongoing for decades.
    * NCHIP was designed to implement federal mandates to enhance criminal history records systems.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) created the Superfund program in 1980 to clean up highly contaminated hazardous waste sites.
	• EPA investigates contaminated areas and places the most highly contaminated sites on the National Priorities List (NPL) for study and cleanup.
	• The cleanup remedy selected depends on the site's characteristics, such as types and levels of contamination, risks to human health and the environment, and applicable cleanup standards.
	• Incineration is one of the cleanup remedies used at Superfund sites, involving burning contaminated substances in an enclosed area to convert contamination into residual products.
• EPA establishes specific cleanup standards for each incinerator used at a Superfund site, based on studies of the site's characteristics and requirements from other environmental programs or laws.
	• Operating parameters are set for the incinerator to achieve emissions standards, tested through a "trial burn" required under RCRA.
	• EPA requires engineering controls to prevent emissions standards from being exceeded and incinerators to have emergency systems to prevent excessive emissions in case of shutdown.
	• EPA relies on 24-hour on-site oversight, air monitoring, and continuous inspections to ensure safe operation of incinerators at Superfund sites.
</summary>

<summary>
• SEC's financial statements for fiscal years 2007 and 2006 were presented fairly in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
	• Misstatements may occur in other financial information due to internal control deficiencies.
• SEC did not maintain effective internal control over financial reporting as of September 30, 2007.
	• Material weakness in financial reporting process identified, including issues with period-end reporting and preparing financial statement disclosures.
• Significant deficiencies in internal control were identified, including property and equipment controls and accounting for budgetary resources.
	• Weaknesses in controls over information security were also noted.
• Errors were found in SEC's calculation of accounts receivable for disgorgements and penalties, as well as in accounting for transaction fee revenue.
	• Errors in financial statement disclosures were also identified, indicating a lack of documented processes.
• Control deficiencies in information security, property and equipment, and accounting for budgetary resources were noted.
	• SEC's management is responsible for preparing financial statements, establishing internal control, and complying with laws and regulations.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Postal Service had about 765,000 career employees at the end of fiscal year 1997.
	* Service employees include craft employees, EAS, PCES, and inspectors for the Postal Inspection Service.
* The EAS workforce consists primarily of employees in EAS 11 through 26 positions.
	* EAS management-level positions begin at EAS 16 and include postmasters and managers.
* The Service created a Diversity Development Department in 1992 to support recruitment, retention, and upward mobility of women and minorities.
	* The Department reports to the Deputy Postmaster General and is responsible for fostering an all-inclusive business environment.
* Aguirre International conducted a 6-month study on workforce diversity at the Postal Service in 1997.
	* The study found that women and minorities faced challenges advancing to management positions at EAS 17 and above.
* The Service developed an action plan in response to the Aguirre report's findings.
	* The plan included 23 initiatives aimed at improving diversity and addressing diversity issues.
* The Service is in the process of establishing targets and measures to assess progress towards meeting diversity goals.
	* The Service is working on improving data collection methods to track diversity-related information.
* The Service has faced challenges in capturing and using EEO data on promotion applicants to identify barriers to the promotion of women and minorities.
	* Efforts are being made to improve the capture and use of diversity-related data to achieve diversity objectives.
</summary>

<summary>
• DOD defines MWDs as canines bred to meet DOD's requirements for operations in protection of installations, resources, and personnel
	• MWDs can be adopted after their military service, with priorities given to former handlers and others capable of caring for them
• The Army provides medical care for MWDs, with preventative care recommended for common breeds used in the MWD program
	• Assistance with privately provided veterinary care is available through nonprofit organizations, such as the U.S. War Dogs Association
</summary>

<summary>
* The Comanche program was established in 1983 to replace the Army’s light helicopter fleet.
    * Contractor team of Sikorsky Aircraft Corporation and Boeing Helicopter Company were expected to design a low-cost, lightweight, advanced technology helicopter.
    * Critical to achieving capabilities are advanced technologies like composite materials, avionics, and propulsion systems.
    * Army must meet ambitious maintainability goals to lower operating costs and achieve wartime operational availability.
* In December 1994, the Secretary of Defense directed the Army to restructure the Comanche helicopter program due to budget constraints.
    * Funding reduced from $4.2 billion to $2.2 billion for fiscal years 1996 through 2001.
    * Development phase extended by 3 years, production decision deferred, and two flyable prototypes to be produced.
* Army proposed a program restructure to acquire six additional aircraft by deferring developmental efforts to fiscal year 2002 and beyond.
    * DOD approved the proposal in March 1995.
    * Operational testing will not begin until after low-rate initial production decision is made, continuing risks associated with concurrency.
* Comanche program experienced significant cost increases, with estimated total program acquisition cost for 1,292 aircraft exceeding $44 billion.
    * Program acquisition unit cost increased by 185% from 1985 estimate.
    * Secretary’s decision and Army’s restructure increased risk of higher total program cost and cost per aircraft.
* Software development, maintainability, and weight growth issues pose risks to the Comanche program.
    * High turnover of software engineers, delays in software development and testing, and configuration management problems.
    * Maintainability requirements such as direct MMH/FH, MTTR, and fault isolation may not be achievable, affecting operating costs and wartime availability goals.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Food Stamp Program provides eligible low-income households with paper coupons or electronic benefits that can be redeemed for food in stores nationwide.
	• FNS funds food stamp benefits and about half of the states’ administrative costs and establishes regulations for implementing the Food Stamp Program.
	• FNS regulations require states to certify household eligibility at least annually and establish requirements for households to report changes that occur after certification.
	• FNS introduced options and waivers to food stamp rules to increase program access, reduce reporting burden on working families, and minimize payment errors.
	• States determine eligibility based on income and assets, with households not exceeding 130% of the federal poverty level and assets not exceeding $2,000 to qualify for benefits.
</summary>

<summary>
* HUD is a federal agency established in 1965 responsible for housing assistance, community development, housing finance, and regulatory issues.
	* HUD has 9,386 employees as of February 1999.
* Housing assistance programs include public housing, private-market housing assistance, and Section 8 assistance.
	* Benefits are limited by budget constraints to about one-fourth of those eligible.
* Community development programs provide funds for economic development, housing development, and assistance to the homeless.
	* Grants are provided to states, metropolitan areas, cities, towns, and counties.
* Housing finance programs include FHA insurance for lenders and guarantees for investors.
	* The Government National Mortgage Association guarantees timely payments on securities.
* Regulatory issues include lead-based paint abatement, fair housing programs, and enforcing federal fair housing laws.
	* HUD's budget request for fiscal year 2000 is about $28 billion in new discretionary budget authority.
* Concerns are raised about HUD's capacity to manage an increase in programs due to ongoing organizational reform.
	* Questions are raised about the accuracy of budget proposals for the Section 8 housing assistance program.
* Issues are raised about the quality of information in HUD's Integrated Disbursement and Information System (IDIS).
	* Concerns are raised about the security of IDIS and the potential for unapproved access to program funds.
* HUD is proposing new initiatives and programs for fiscal year 2000, including set-asides within existing programs.
	* Concerns are raised about HUD's ability to administer new contracting initiatives due to weaknesses in contracting practices.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Military Health System operated by DOD has a dual health care mission—readiness and benefits.
	• Readiness mission provides medical services during contingency operations.
• Benefits mission provides medical services to members of the armed forces and their families.
	• DOD's health care mission is carried out through military treatment facilities and TRICARE.
• In 2008, plans were approved to renovate LRMC and the 86th MDG clinic.
	• Plans included consolidating the two projects into one new facility.
• The replacement medical center will serve as the only tertiary-level referral hospital for multiple theaters of operation.
	• The facility is being designed with the flexibility to expand during surges for contingency operations.
• DOD's cost estimating methodology for the replacement medical center substantially met best practices criteria but was only minimally documented.
	• DOD agreed with recommendations to provide clear documentation on facility requirements and revise the cost estimate.
</summary>

<summary>
* ICE estimates the alien population subject to removal to be around 12 million as of March 2006.
	* DHS reported an increase in the removable alien population from 2000 to 2006.
		* Aliens in violation of immigration laws are subject to removal for various reasons.
		* ICE officers exercise discretion in various phases of the alien apprehension and removal process.
		* Officers have more latitude to exercise discretion for aliens with humanitarian issues.
	* ICE has policies and procedures in place to guide officer decision-making during the removal process.
		* Officers are required to document specific immigration charges and custody decisions.
		* Supervisors review and authorize decisions made by officers.
		* ICE has an inspection program to oversee field offices' compliance with policies and procedures.
	* ICE lacks a mechanism to collect and analyze data on officers' exercise of discretion.
		* ICE is planning to update its data systems to provide more capabilities for tracking alien apprehensions.
		* ICE should evaluate the costs and alternatives of developing a reporting mechanism for analyzing trends in the use of discretion.
</summary>

<summary>
* Ground ambulance services are provided by a variety of organizations with different structures, staffing types, and revenue sources.
    * Providers may be affiliated with institutions or independent, for-profit, nonprofit, or government-based.
    * They may rely on volunteers, paid staff, or a combination of both.
    * Revenue sources include community tax support, charitable donations, grants, and payments from Medicare, Medicaid, and private insurance.
    * Medicare payments for ambulance services consist of a service-level payment and a mileage payment.
    * The service-level payment is based on the type of transport provided, while the mileage payment is determined by the number of miles traveled.
* Providers' costs for ground ambulance transports vary widely, with personnel costs being the largest expense.
    * Costs per transport ranged from $224 to $2,204 in 2010.
    * Super-rural providers had significantly higher costs per transport compared to urban providers.
    * Medicare margins for providers in 2010 were about 2 percent, but decreased to -1 percent when add-on payments were removed.
* Ambulance transports for Medicare beneficiaries increased by 33 percent from 2004 to 2010, with the largest growth in BLS nonemergency transports.
    * The increase in transports was not attributed to changes in demographic characteristics of beneficiaries.
    * Some of the increase in ambulance transports was due to increased billing for Medicare services at the local-government level.
    * HHS OIG found that improper payments for ambulance services were primarily for nonemergency transports, including transports for dialysis services.
* Regression analysis showed that total costs for providers were significantly affected by total transports, government subsidies, and percentage of nonemergency Medicare transports.
    * Providers with higher government subsidies tended to have higher costs.
    * The use of volunteer staff did not significantly contribute to differences in total costs.
</summary>

<summary>
• Supply Chain Integration office under the Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Logistics & Materiel Readiness is responsible for leading DOD supply chain policies and improving accountability of SRC I ammunition.
	• Army plays a prominent role in managing SRC I ammunition, procuring a majority of the department's ammunition and providing storage for other military services.
		• Army depots conduct semiannual physical inventories of all SRC I ammunition as required.
		• SRC I ammunition may also be located at retail locations such as military service installations and bases.
		• Each military service has entities responsible for accountability, physical inventory, and transportation of SRC I ammunition.
• USTRANSCOM is designated as the DOD's single manager for transportation of SRC I ammunition.
	• Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command tracks movement of SRC I ammunition.
	• Coordination of transportation issues of SRC I ammunition in transit is done by the Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command.
• DOD policy requires SRC I ammunition to have a higher level of protection and security than other conventional ammunition.
	• Policy and guidance are in place for accountability, safeguarding, physical inventories, tracking, and shipping of SRC I ammunition.
	• Military services have automated information systems for managing accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition.
• DOD is evaluating various automated information systems to designate one as the authoritative source of data for conventional ammunition, including SRC I ammunition.
	• Evaluation is in response to a congressional mandate to issue department-wide guidance by September 2015.
	• The designated visibility system will serve as a repository of ammunition data collected through regular data feeds from military services' automated information systems.
• GAO made 6 recommendations to enhance DOD policy and procedures and improve accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition.
	• Recommendations include revising guidance for accountability, finalizing guidance for receipting SRC I ammunition, evaluating actions for retaining accountability of in-transit items, determining specific information for timely data entry into DTTS, and conducting analysis of completeness and accuracy of data entered into DTTS.
	• DOD concurred with all recommendations and provided details on actions taken to address each recommendation.
</summary>

<summary>
• The federal government is the largest producer, collector, and user of information in the US.
	• Federal agencies collect personal information such as name, date of birth, address, and SSNs.
		• This information is used to provide services and benefits under the law.
		• SSA administers income support programs and issues SSNs.
		• Information collected is protected by statute and regulation.
• The Privacy Act of 1974 governs the protection of personal privacy by federal agencies.
	• Agencies must inform individuals of the purpose of information collection.
		• Information can only be disclosed with consent or under specific exceptions.
		• Agencies must keep accurate records of disclosures.
• SSA's disclosure policy is more restrictive than other federal agencies.
	• Information can be shared with law enforcement under certain conditions.
		• SSA considers factors such as nature of criminal activity before sharing information.
		• SSA's OIG can disclose information under an MOU with law enforcement.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) aims to minimize threats to human health and the environment from hazardous waste.
	• RCRA governs the management of hazardous waste from generation to disposal.
• EPA has established criteria for identifying hazardous waste, including specific types and characteristics.
	• Waste from both current and past industrial operations is regulated.
• RCRA requirements can negatively affect cleanups, with land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and permit requirements being the most significant barriers.
	• Compliance with these requirements can be costly and time-consuming.
• EPA has developed policy and regulatory alternatives to mitigate the impact of RCRA requirements on remediation waste.
	• Stakeholders have varied experiences with these alternatives, with some finding them burdensome and inefficient.
• EPA proposed a comprehensive rule in 1996 to reform RCRA's requirements for managing remediation waste, but plans to withdraw it due to disagreements among stakeholders.
	• EPA believes that comprehensive reform of RCRA's requirements for remediation waste is best achieved through legislation.
</summary>

<summary>
* Medicare program integrity activities were previously funded under Medicare's general administrative budget, leading to funding constraints and reduced ability to conduct audits and review medical claims.
	* Funding for program integrity activities was constrained by ongoing Medicare program operations and budget procedures imposed under the Budget Enforcement Act of 1990.
	* HHS advocated for dedicated and stable program integrity funding outside of the annual appropriations process to allow for multiyear planning.
	* HIPAA established the Medicare Integrity Program (MIP) in 1997, providing dedicated funding for program integrity activities.
	* MIP funds are primarily allocated to support contractors' program integrity efforts for the traditional fee-for-service Medicare program.
	* Contractors receive MIP funds to perform audits, medical reviews, secondary payer activities, benefit integrity efforts, and provider education.
	* CMS increased funding for each of the five program integrity activities from fiscal years 1997 to 2005, with provider education receiving the largest percentage increase.
	* CMS plans to use additional funding provided under DRA to address potential fraud, waste, and abuse in the new Medicare prescription drug benefit.
	* CMS is developing initiatives to measure the effectiveness of audit and provider education activities and plans to allocate funds based on effectiveness, workload, and risk.
</summary>

<summary>
• TSA has had concerns about the performance of passenger and checked baggage screeners in detecting threat objects at airports.
	• In the late 1990s, screeners' abilities to detect dangerous objects declined as testing objects became more realistic.
• After the 9/11 attacks, the Aviation and Transportation Security Act was signed into law to strengthen aviation security.
	• ATSA created TSA as an agency responsible for securing all modes of transportation, including aviation.
• TSA oversees security operations at over 450 commercial airports, classifying them into security risk categories based on various factors.
	• Each Federal Security Director (FSD) is responsible for overseeing security activities at one or more commercial airports.
• TSA implemented a basic screener training program with classroom instruction and on-the-job training.
	• TSA also conducts annual proficiency reviews, operational testing, and requires remedial training for screeners.
• TSA has faced challenges in providing access to recurrent training due to staffing shortages and lack of high-speed Internet/intranet connectivity at some training facilities.
	• TSA has taken steps to enhance training by adding a dual-function screening course, an Online Learning Center, and hands-on training tools.
• TSA has made progress in measuring and enhancing screener performance, including increasing covert testing, deploying the Threat Image Projection system, and completing recertification programs.
	• TSA is working on developing an image recognition module for checked baggage screeners and establishing performance targets for screening indexes.
</summary>

<summary>
* IRS has 10,000 customer service representatives at 25 call sites around the country.
	* IRS began operating as a single call center in 1999, providing round-the-clock service.
	* Calls were routed based on hold times and subject coverage.
	* IRS expanded toll-free network coverage in 1999 to 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
* The Operations Center manages the call center network.
	* Responsible for forecasting call demand and routing calls among sites.
	* Develops staffing requirements and monitors site adherence.
	* Controls call traffic status and reroutes calls when necessary.
* IRS faces challenges in determining staffing levels for its customer service workforce.
	* Annual funding is based on balancing efforts to assist taxpayers and ensure compliance.
	* IRS lacks a long-term service-level goal based on taxpayer needs.
	* Industry practices base goals and staffing on customer needs.
* IRS is working on improving its recruiting, training, and retaining of customer service representatives.
	* Challenges include difficulties in recruiting due to job characteristics.
	* Training representatives on a broad range of topics with limited resources.
	* Retaining skilled representatives and scheduling staff effectively.
* IRS is implementing an automated system to forecast demand, schedule staff, and track adherence to schedules.
	* Inaccurate forecasting led to inefficient scheduling and underutilization of staff.
	* The system is expected to use historical data to forecast call demand accurately.
	* The system is still being refined to handle the complexity of IRS' toll-free operations.
* IRS needs to improve its evaluation of human capital management practices.
	* Evaluations focus on short-term improvements rather than long-term strategic planning.
	* Evaluations do not consider the interrelationships among human capital practices.
	* Other organizations evaluate the effects of changes in one practice on other practices and overall results.
* Recommendations for IRS include establishing long-term service-level goals, assessing competency gaps, monitoring attrition, and evaluating human capital practices.
	* Establish a system for assessing competency gaps and meeting refresher training needs.
	* Develop a system for monitoring attrition and identifying causes.
	* Ensure evaluations consider the effects of human capital practices on achieving customer service goals.
</summary>

<summary>
• Mortgage lenders keep loans in primary or secondary markets
	• Primary market: lenders keep loans or sell them in secondary market
		• Secondary market: purchasers hold loans in portfolios or pool them for MBS
		• Secondary markets benefit lenders, borrowers, and investors
		• Ginnie Mae operates as a unit of HUD
• Ginnie Mae's mission is to expand affordable housing in America
	• Ginnie Mae does not buy or sell loans or issue MBS
	• Ginnie Mae provides guarantees backed by the U.S. government
	• Ginnie Mae's MBS programs include Ginnie Mae I, Ginnie Mae II, and Multiclass Securities Program
• Ginnie Mae faces challenges in adjusting to market changes
	• Ginnie Mae has taken initiatives to improve its product offerings
	• Ginnie Mae faces challenges in managing internal operations and ensuring data integrity
	• Ginnie Mae must address potential implications of changes in market share and guarantee volume
</summary>

<summary>
• DOD has reversed $592 million of illegal and improper adjustments out of $615 million identified, but additional accounting errors have been uncovered.
	• Reversing adjustments led to more errors that need to be corrected, requiring significant time and effort.
		• DFAS Columbus estimates over 21,000 hours needed to correct accounting for 30 contracts.
		• Reversing adjustments for one contract led to $85.4 million in negative unliquidated obligations.
		• DFAS Columbus estimates over 2,300 hours needed to reaudit and correct one contract.
		• Reversing adjustments for another contract led to $100 million in illegal or improper adjustments.
		• DFAS Columbus estimates over 1,850 hours needed to reaudit and correct this contract.
• DOD made $291 million of illegal or improper adjustments in fiscal year 2001, with $172 million identified as such.
	• DOD agreed to reverse and correct the $172 million of adjustments.
		• DOD plans to review an additional $1.1 billion of fiscal year 2001 adjustments.
		• DFAS Columbus estimates several hundred contracts and about 1,000 adjustments will need detailed reviews.
		• DOD plans to have all reviews and reversals completed by December 31, 2002.
• DOD has taken actions to eliminate illegal adjustments, resulting in an 80% reduction in closed account adjustments in the first 6 months of fiscal year 2002.
	• DFAS implemented controls to prevent illegal adjustments, resulting in a decline in closed account adjustments.
		• DFAS identified and corrected $253,212 of illegal adjustments in the CRS system.
		• DFAS upgraded the CRS system to prevent illegal adjustments from occurring.
• Options for Congress to consider include prohibiting adjustments to closed accounts or allowing a limited period for adjustments after an account is closed.
	• Prohibiting adjustments could eliminate errors but may impact DOD's ability to pay for goods and services.
		• Allowing a limited period for adjustments could provide time to correct errors immediately after an account is closed.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Internet has grown in importance for American businesses and consumers, supporting commerce and vital services.
	• The domain name system ensures the uniqueness of each e-mail and Web site address.
• The U.S. government supported the implementation of the domain name system and began transitioning technical responsibility to the private sector in 1997.
	• The Department of Commerce issued a general statement of policy known as the "White Paper" to guide the transition.
• ICANN made progress in promoting competition by certifying more registrars and reducing the cost of securing domain names.
	• Progress has been slower in addressing other guiding principles such as stability, security, and representation in domain name policy-making.
• Efforts to enhance the stability and security of the Internet, formalize relationships with entities involved in running the domain name system, and expand the pool of domain names have been behind schedule.
	• The domain name system is critical to the stability and security of the entire Internet.
• ICANN's reform efforts have been initiated due to challenges in accomplishing the transition, with proposed changes to the structure and operations.
	• The Department of Commerce is responsible for overseeing the transition and determining ICANN's capability to manage the domain name system.
</summary>

<summary>
* The federal government has held funds in trust for Indian tribes since 1820.
	* Enacted in 1887, the General Allotment Act provided for the division of Indian tribal lands into allotments for individual tribal members and families.
* The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 ended the allotment of tribal lands and extended the period that the federal government would hold allotted lands in trust.
	* The Secretary of the Interior is responsible for managing trust funds, providing trust services, and maintaining official Indian land title records.
* Interior issued the Comprehensive Trust Management Plan in 2003 to guide trust reform efforts.
	* The plan serves as a foundation for recommendations for reengineered business processes.
* Interior contracted with Electronic Data Systems in 2001 to improve trust reforms.
	* The Secretary reorganized BIA and OST in 2003 to improve trust management.
* OST's budget and staff have increased to implement reforms and support other Indian-related activities.
	* OST is responsible for trust fund management, maintaining trust records, and developing trust investment strategies.
* OST has implemented key trust fund management reforms, such as the Trust Funds Accounting System and the Trust Beneficiary Call Center.
	* Additional reforms are planned, including verifying TAAMS information and implementing an Appraisal Management System.
* Interior has provided retention allowances and performance awards to SES managers at OST.
	* The average performance award amounts for OST's SES managers were generally lower than those at other bureaus and offices within Interior and other federal agencies.
</summary>

<summary>
• VA and DOD initiated the Government Computer-Based Patient Record (GCPR) project in 1998 to share patient health information for active duty military personnel and veterans.
	• Lack of clear mission and detailed planning hindered progress of the GCPR project.
	• Recommendations were made to strengthen management and oversight of the project.

• VA and DOD later renamed the project the Federal Health Information Exchange (FHIE) program, allowing for the exchange of health care information in two phases.
	• Phase one enabled one-way transfer of data from DOD to VA clinicians.
	• Phase two added to the base of patient health information available to VA clinicians.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) outlines the desired outcome of an income tax audit as determining the correct taxable income and tax liability.
	• The auditor is responsible for conducting a quality audit to ensure accuracy.
		• IRS uses nine audit standards to define audit quality, addressing scope, techniques, technical conclusions, reports, and time management.
		• Workpapers are crucial for documenting audit scope, procedures, evidence, and technical conclusions.
		• Audit workpapers are reviewed by group managers to identify and correct quality issues.
• Workpapers are essential for supporting the auditor's report on the taxpayer's correct tax liability.
	• IRS' Examination Quality Measurement System (EQMS) collects information on audit quality and process improvements.
		• EQMS staff review audit workpapers to assess compliance with audit standards.
		• Audits must pass all key elements of the standards to be considered successful.
• Despite efforts to control quality, there have been issues with the quality of IRS audit workpapers.
	• Problems identified include discrepancies in tax adjustments, missing or incomplete documentation, and lack of legibility.
		• IRS has historically found problems with the quality of its workpapers.
		• Supervisory review of audit workpapers is a primary quality control mechanism.
</summary>

<summary>
* Congress authorized State’s ATA program in 1983 through the Foreign Assistance Act.
	* Purpose of ATA:
		* Enhance antiterrorism skills of friendly countries
		* Strengthen bilateral ties with friendly governments
* ATA offers training courses and grants of equipment to partner nations.
	* Training focuses on critical counterterrorism capabilities.
		* Covers crisis management, cyberterrorism, dignitary protection, etc.
* ATA is State’s largest counterterrorism program.
	* Receives appropriations under the Nonproliferation, Anti-Terrorism, Demining, and Related Programs account.
* S/CT and DS/T/ATA did not systematically use country-specific needs assessments and program reviews to plan assistance.
	* S/CT places countries on a tiered list based on various factors.
* S/CT and DS/T/ATA lacked clear measures and processes for assessing sustainability.
	* State did not have measurable performance goals and outcomes related to ATA's objectives.
* State did not comply with a congressional mandate to report on U.S. international counterterrorism assistance.
	* ATA annual reports contained inaccurate data and lacked systematic assessments of program results.
* Deficiencies in how the program is guided, managed, implemented, and assessed could limit effectiveness.
	* Minimal guidance from S/CT makes it difficult to determine if program assistance supports U.S. counterterrorism policy goals.
</summary>

<summary>
* Large financial companies can be reorganized or liquidated through judicial bankruptcy or special resolution regimes.
	* Bankruptcy is a federal court procedure to help eliminate or restructure debts.
	* Equitable treatment of creditors is important in bankruptcy proceedings.
* Chapter 7 and Chapter 11 of the Code govern liquidation and reorganization proceedings.
	* Debtors can voluntarily or involuntarily file for bankruptcy.
	* Chapter 7 involves a trustee taking over assets and making distributions to creditors.
	* Chapter 11 allows debtors to continue operations under court supervision.
* The U.S. bankruptcy system involves multiple federal entities.
	* Bankruptcy courts are located in 90 federal judicial districts.
	* The Federal Judicial Center assists bankruptcy courts with reports and assessments.
* The Dodd-Frank Act amended the Federal Reserve Act to prohibit emergency lending programs for specific companies.
	* The Federal Reserve may design emergency lending programs for the financial system.
* Safe harbor provisions in bankruptcy pertain to financial and derivative contracts.
	* These provisions allow counterparties to exercise certain rights even during bankruptcy.
* The Orderly Liquidation Authority (OLA) gives FDIC the authority to resolve large financial companies outside of bankruptcy.
	* OLA allows for the creation of a bridge company to maintain critical services.
* Efforts are being made to improve cross-border coordination for the resolution of failed large financial companies.
	* International bodies have issued principles to guide resolution regimes for financial firms.
	* The ISDA Resolution Stay Protocol was established to facilitate cross-border resolutions.
</summary>

<summary>
* The electricity industry consists of four functions: generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations.
	* Electricity is generated through various means and sent through transmission lines to local distributors.
	* Local distributors transform electricity into lower voltage for consumption by consumers.
* System operators constantly balance generation and consumption of power to ensure smooth flow.
	* Utilities own and operate electricity assets, including generation plants and transmission lines.
* The smart grid vision aims to increase efficiency, reliability, and integration of renewable energy sources.
	* Smart grid systems use IT systems and networks for automation and real-time information for consumers.
* Federal and state governments oversee the electricity industry, with FERC regulating wholesale rates and transmission.
	* NERC ensures reliability of the bulk power system and develops and enforces mandatory standards.
* Cyber threats to the electricity industry are evolving and can come from various sources.
	* Threats include unintentional causes like natural disasters and intentional attacks from criminal groups or foreign nations.
* Various entities, including NERC, NIST, FERC, and DHS, have taken steps to secure the electricity grid.
	* NERC has developed critical infrastructure standards, while NIST has identified cybersecurity standards for smart grid systems.
* Challenges in securing the electricity grid include monitoring cybersecurity standards implementation and clarifying regulatory responsibilities.
	* A comprehensive approach to cybersecurity, built-in security features in smart grid systems, and effective information sharing are essential.
</summary>

<summary>
• Federal workforce faces skills gaps in mission-critical areas
    • Shortfalls in cybersecurity, acquisitions, and agency-specific roles hinder government effectiveness
    • Reasons for skills gaps include insufficient number of skilled employees and lack of appropriate skills
    • Budget pressures, changing nature of work, and potential wave of retirements exacerbate skills gap issues
    • Recommendations include modernizing classification system, improving hiring process, and linking pay to performance
</summary>

<summary>
* About 90 percent of the costs associated with GWOT fall into military personnel and operation and maintenance accounts.
	* Military personnel funds cover pay and allowances of mobilized reservists, special payments for qualifying military personnel, and allowances like Imminent Danger Pay.
	* Operation and maintenance funds are used for transportation, unit operating support, intelligence, communications, and logistics support.
	* Estimating ongoing military operations costs is difficult due to changing operational requirements during the fiscal year.
	* DOD uses transfer authority to shift funds between appropriation accounts and reprogramming to shift funds within specific accounts.
	* In fiscal years 2004 and 2005, military services received supplemental appropriations for GWOT expenses.
	* DOD increased annual appropriation requests by more than $10 billion per year to support GWOT.
	* The military services received additional funds in their annual appropriations to support military operations in the war on terrorism.
	* The military services projected gaps between reported obligations and supplemental appropriations for fiscal year 2005.
	* DOD and the military services plan to take actions to cover any gaps and meet GWOT needs, including reprogramming funds and reducing planned spending.
</summary>

<summary>
* The financial crisis prompted extraordinary government interventions to stabilize the financial system.
	* Interventions included providing capital to financial institutions, enhancing access to liquid assets, purchasing nonperforming assets, guaranteeing liabilities, intervening in financial markets, and mitigating home foreclosures.
	* Programs were categorized based on their focus on specific institutions, markets, or individuals.
* Treasury extended TARP to address weaknesses in the economy and respond to unanticipated shocks.
	* Coordination with the Federal Reserve and FDIC was emphasized in the decision-making process.
	* The decision was based on ongoing weaknesses in housing, commercial real estate, and labor markets, as well as global economic risks.
* Treasury used quantitative indicators such as housing market indicators, loan originations, and credit spreads to inform decisions.
	* Indicators were used to assess the impact of programs and determine the need for additional resources.
	* Clear program objectives were identified to improve transparency and analytical basis for decision-making.
* Treasury formalized coordination with the FDIC for decisions associated with the expiration of TARP.
	* Coordination was achieved through FinSOB meetings, bilateral meetings, or other forums for structured dialogue.
	* Treasury publicly identified clear program objectives and set quantitative goals for small business lending programs.
</summary>

<summary>
* USDA and FDA are responsible for ensuring the safety of meat, poultry, and certain egg products, as well as all other foods, respectively.
	* FDA and FSIS work to ensure the safety of food products through a regulatory system of preventive controls known as HACCP.
* FDA and FSIS conduct inspections to verify that food processors are implementing their HACCP plans.
	* FDA inspects over 57,000 food facilities every 5 years on average, while USDA inspects over 6,000 meat and poultry facilities daily.
* Both agencies have the authority to take enforcement actions to ensure facilities meet safety and sanitation requirements.
	* In fiscal year 1999, FDA, FSIS, and states spent about $1.3 billion on food safety activities.
* After September 11, 2001, efforts were intensified to address potential deliberate contamination of agriculture and food products.
	* FDA and USDA received emergency funding to prevent, prepare for, and respond to potential bioterrorist attacks.
* FDA and USDA have taken actions to better protect the food supply against deliberate contamination.
	* FDA has hired new food safety investigators and participated in exercises to enhance emergency response procedures.
* USDA has formed a Homeland Security Council and Office of Food Security and Emergency Preparedness to coordinate security efforts.
	* USDA has increased the number of import inspectors and conducted risk assessments for domestic and imported food.
* FDA and FSIS issued voluntary security guidelines to food-processing industry to enhance security measures.
	* State governments have also provided guidelines and enacted legislation to address food security.
* FDA and FSIS inspectors have observed a range of security measures being implemented at food-processing facilities.
	* Inspectors are encouraged to discuss security measures with facility management but are not authorized to enforce these measures.
* The food industry is voluntarily taking steps to prevent deliberate contamination of products.
	* Trade associations have issued their own security guidelines and formed alliances to exchange information on food security.
* FDA and USDA lack comprehensive information on the extent to which food processors are implementing security measures.
	* Both agencies have instructed field inspection personnel not to document security measures due to concerns about public disclosure.
</summary>

<summary>
* The MAS program is the largest interagency contracting vehicle managed by GSA.
	* MACs, GWACs, and enterprisewide contracts are also used by government buyers.
* Fees are paid for using other agencies' contracts, usually a percentage of the procurement value.
	* These fees cover the costs of administering the contract.
* ID/IQ contracts are used to buy goods and services when future quantities are unknown.
	* Task and delivery orders are placed against these contracts.
* In fiscal year 2008, federal agencies spent at least $60 billion through various contracts.
	* Sales under the MAS program have been relatively flat in recent years.
* Concerns exist about contract duplication and lack of reliable data on interagency contracts.
	* Limited governmentwide policy is in place for establishing and overseeing MACs and enterprisewide contracts.
* Recent legislation and OFPP initiatives aim to strengthen oversight of MACs.
	* GSA faces challenges in managing the MAS program effectively.
* GSA lacks transactional data on MAS contracts and uses limited pricing tools.
	* GSA's management structure for the MAS program is decentralized.
* GSA should collect transactional data on MAS orders and improve pricing tools.
	* GSA should target pre-award audits to cover more contracts and implement a consistent review process.
* The federal government lacks a clear view of who is using interagency and enterprisewide contracts.
	* Long-standing problems with data quality and lack of consistent policy hinder the government's ability to realize the strategic value of these contracts.
</summary>

<summary>
* Investments in IT can enrich people’s lives and improve organizational performance.
	* The Internet has matured into a national resource for citizens to interact with the government.
* Some federally funded IT projects have become risky, costly, and unproductive mistakes.
	* Examples include failed projects like the Office of Personnel Management’s Retirement Systems Modernization program.
* 18F and USDS were formed to address troubled IT efforts in the federal government.
	* 18F provides expert designers, developers, and technologists to help deploy digital services.
* 18F is funded through the Acquisition Services Fund and aims to achieve full cost recovery by fiscal year 2019.
	* The program uses special hiring authorities and provides services through interagency agreements.
* USDS aims to transform important digital services for citizens by partnering with government agencies.
	* The program recruits private sector experts to improve the usefulness and reliability of digital services.
* Both 18F and USDS have provided a variety of development and consulting services to federal agencies.
	* Most surveyed agency project managers were satisfied with the services provided by 18F and USDS.
</summary>

<summary>
* The baby boom generation will soon begin moving from working ages to retirement ages, leading to changes in the aged dependency ratio.
	* Aged dependency ratio will rise from 21% in 2000 to 35% by 2030.
	* Labor force growth is slowing, with a projected annual rate of 0.3% from 2000 to 2025.
	* Social Security retirement policy changes aim to strengthen incentives to work longer.
* The Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 promotes employment of older persons based on ability rather than age.
	* ADEA applies to firms with 20 or more employees.
	* Equal Employment Opportunity Commission enforces ADEA.
	* Some states have laws protecting older workers in small businesses.
* Pension benefits influence work decisions of older individuals.
	* Federal government provides preferential tax treatment for pension plans meeting certain requirements.
	* ERISA establishes minimum standards for private employee pension plans.
	* Pension laws relating to defined benefit plans may discourage employment after eligibility for benefits.
* Older workers are employed in a diverse range of occupations, with a growing proportion in white-collar occupations.
	* By 2015, older workers are projected to be about 20% of the total workforce.
	* Older workers are projected to make gains in earnings between 2000 and 2008.
	* The composition of the older workforce is shifting towards white-collar occupations.
* Employers are using various arrangements to retain and extend the careers of older workers.
	* Flexible employment arrangements include part-time work, consulting, and reduced work schedules.
	* Public employers are more active in implementing programs to retain older workers.
	* Private sector flexible employment programs are limited in scope.
* Factors discouraging continued labor force participation of older workers include negative perceptions, higher costs, and health problems.
	* Employers may discriminate against older workers.
